headline: Warwickshire County Council vote sees Reform become largest party - BBC News
context: Nigel Clarke, Reform UK chair for Warwick and Leamington, said his party was happy to work with the Conservatives at a local level

annotations.paragraph: The Conservatives have lost control of Warwickshire County Council amid a Reform surge seen in several councils across England.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides essential information about the change in control of the council and the Reform party's surge.

annotations.paragraph: Tory council leader Izzi Seccombe, who had led the council for nearly 12 years, lost her seat to David Curtis, from the Liberal Democrats, and the final tally left the authority under no overall control.
annotations.reason: This paragraph gives specific details about the loss of a key Conservative leader and the resulting political situation.

annotations.paragraph: Big gains were seen by both the Liberal Democrat and Green Party groups, while Reform became the largest party on the authority with 23 seats, but was unable to secure a majority.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides important details about the election results and the distribution of seats.

annotations.paragraph: Liberal Democrats now form the second largest block with 14 seats.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific information about the seat distribution, relevant to the election outcome.

annotations.paragraph: The Conservative group has nine, the Green Party has seven, Labour has three and Whitnash Residents Association has one.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides detailed information on the seat distribution among different parties.

annotations.paragraph: The council previously had a strong Conservative majority, holding 41 of 57 seats
annotations.reason: Provides context on the previous political landscape of the council.

annotations.paragraph: The Liberal Democrats now form the second largest block
annotations.reason: Gives information on the current political composition of the council.

annotations.paragraph: One of the youngest councillors to be elected was George Finch, for Reform, who, at the age of 18, took the Bedworth Central seat, with 1,563 votes.
annotations.reason: Highlights a notable election result and a significant detail about a young councillor.

annotations.paragraph: Judith Falps, from Whitnash Residents Association, who polled 939 votes to edge past Reform in her seat, described the outcome of the local elections as a "wake-up call" for major parties.
annotations.reason: Provides a perspective on the election outcome and its implications for major parties.

annotations.paragraph: Liberal Democrat group deputy leader, Sarah Boad, re-elected for Leamington North, said most of Warwickshire's portfolio holders lost their seats and residents were going to get a "completely new broom" with a new set of people in charge.
annotations.reason: Offers insight into the election's impact on council leadership and future changes.

annotations.paragraph: With control of the council now up in the air, Nigel Clarke, chairman of the Warwick and Leamington branch of Reform, said his party was happy to work with the Conservatives at a local level and meetings were already planned.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant information about the political dynamics following the council vote.

annotations.paragraph: "We're way past a protest vote," he said. "We're now at a stage where we understand that Britain is broken. We've had 100 years of Labour and Tories. Reform believe in starting again."
annotations.reason: This paragraph contains a direct quote from a key figure, providing insight into the party's perspective and goals.

annotations.paragraph: Reform's national leader Nigel Farage, speaking in Durham, said the results marked "the end of two-party politics".
annotations.reason: This paragraph includes a significant quote from a national leader, adding context to the political implications of the vote.

annotations.paragraph: One of the youngest councillors to be elected was Reform's George Finch
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific information about a notable election outcome related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Voters told the BBC that priority issues included traffic, climate change, recycling and litter, as well as early years education and social care.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers context on voter priorities, which is relevant to understanding the election results.

annotations.paragraph: Nuneaton's Labour MP Jodie Gosling defended her party's performance and said it was "not unusual" for a government to experience push back.
annotations.reason: Provides commentary on the election results and political context.

annotations.paragraph: She added that she saw support for Reform and the Green Party as indicative of the "disarray of the Conservatives".
annotations.reason: Offers insight into the political dynamics affecting the election outcome.

annotations.paragraph: "There are still many families feeling the pinch," she said, "and the legacy we have been left with is going to take time to clean up."
annotations.reason: Provides context on the socio-economic factors influencing voter sentiment.

annotations.paragraph: Alex Macdonald and Christine Wilson have been helping at elections since 2016
annotations.reason: Does not contribute to the main story about the election results.

annotations.paragraph: Graham Curtis, who was a Conversative candidate for Attleborough, said the results reflected the feeling on doorsteps.
annotations.reason: Provides a direct quote related to the election results.

annotations.paragraph: "A lot of the Reform votes have come from the Conservatives," he said."There seems to be that local feeling of protest and change."
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a quote from a relevant party member about the source of Reform's votes and the local sentiment.

annotations.paragraph: The BBC has approached former leader Izzi Seccombe for comment.
annotations.reason: This paragraph does not provide new information or context relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Tell us which stories we should cover in Warwickshire
annotations.reason: This is a call to action for audience engagement, not relevant to the article's main story.
